pullRequest.body:
This is an attempt to refactor the definition of `rootsOfUnity` using a `Nat` instead of a `PNat`.

* In the definition of `rootsOfUnity`, we replace `(n : â„•+)` by `(n : â„•)`. The definition does not require `n` to be nonzero; it gives that `rootsOfUnity 0 M` is the top subgroup of the unit group of `M`.
* For results that need a positive `n`, we replace `(n : â„•+)` with `(n : â„•) [NeZero n]` in the parameters. In this way, they transparently apply when a `PNat` is used for `n` since `n` gets coerced to `Nat` and an `NeZero (n : â„•)` instance is available.

The main benefit is that one no longer needs constructions like `rootsOfUnity âŸ¨n, <proof that n is positiveâŸ©) R` when `n` is a natural number; one can simply use `rootsOfUnity n R`. (One may need to turn the positivity proof into an `NeZero` instance, however, if that is not available automatically.)

In addition, the code in `Mathlib.RingTheory.RootsOfUnity.Basic` can be simplified a bit in places, e.g., `x ^ (k : â„•)` can be replaced by `x ^ k` and `âˆƒ (i : â„•), i < k âˆ§ P i` can be replaced by `âˆƒ i < k, P i`. One result (`eq_pow_of_mem_rootsOfUnity'`; it was translating between `Nat`s and `PNat`s) can be removed altogether.

Since I was going through this file anyway, I took the opportunity to replace `=>` by `â†¦` and to do some golfing as well.

What this PR does *not* do is also refactoring cyclotomic extensions to not use (sets of) `PNat`s. This is a more complex matter and requires more thought and discussion.

---
